resources.string: You don\'t have any properties at the moment. Click the "+" (plus) button up top to get started.\n\nRental Calc lets you create properties to help determine their investment potential.
Please confirm that you want to delete this property.
If no repairs are required, then this is the same as the purchase price.
Enter your expected tax rate for after tax cash flow calculations.
The price of the property.\n\nThis does not include the purchase costs or costs to repair or update the property.
The estimated market value of the property after repairs and updates.

The costs and fees associated with purchasing the property. These are also called closing costs.\n\nExamples of purchasing costs include: appraisal, property inspection, pest inspection, and homeownersâ€™ insurance for the first year.
The costs for repairing and updating the property.\n\nExamples include paint, flooring, appliances, and cleaning.
The total values of all rents collected from tenants. Does not consider vacancy or expenses.

Any other income besides than that from rents.\n\nThis may include other services provided to tenants, such as yard maintenance, house cleaning, utilities, and coin-operated laundry and vending machine proceeds.
All the expenses paid while renting a property.\n\nExamples include insurance, 3rd party warranties, maintenance, property taxes, and utilities.

The percentage of time the property is expected to not being rented.

Ideally the property will always be rented. However, the property may be vacant between tenants or while repairing or updating it.

Example: if the property is expected to be vacant one month out of the year, this is 1/12=8.3%
The yearly increase of the property\'s value.\n\nThis can be due to a number of reasons, which include increased demand or reduced supply, or inflation.
The yearly increase of the income generated by the property.\n\nInflation is the typical cause of the increase. This affects both the rent and other income from the property.
The yearly increase of the expenses paid while renting the property.\n\nInflation is the typical cause of the increase, and affects all expenses.
The costs and fees associated with selling the property. This is also called closing costs.\n\nExamples include real estate agent commissions, transfer taxes, home warranty, and escrow fees.
The value of the land alone, i.e. the value of the property less the value of the dwelling and other structures.\n\nThis is used in calculating the depreciation deduction of the property.
The total amount of cash needed to purchase the property, repair, and update it.
$$\\text{Total Cash Needed} = \\text{Down Payment} + \\text{Purchase Costs} + \\text{Repair and Update Costs}$$
All the income generated by renting a property, less vacancies.

All the income generated by renting a property, less Operating Expenses.\n\nThis does not take into account loan payments. Because of this, Net Operating Income can be used to compare properties independent of financing.
The amount of money received from a rental property as income.\n\nThis accounts for all income sources and all expenses, including loan payments.

A rate of return on a rental property that compares the yearly Net Operating Income and the Purchase Price.\n\nThis does not take into account loan payments. Because of this, the Capitalization Rate can be used to compare properties independent of financing.
A rate of return on a rental property that compares the yearly Cash Flow and Total Invested Cash.\n\nThis represents the yearly return on the invested cash.
$$\\text{Cash On Cash} = \\frac{\\text{Yearly Cash Flow}}{\\text{Total Invested Cash}}$$
A rate of return on a rental property that compares the monthly Gross Rent and the property\'s Market Value.

A rate of return on a rental property that compares the property\'s Purchase Price and the monthly Gross Rent.\n\nThis represents the number of years it will take for the yearly Gross Rent to add to the purchase price.

The current value of the property.\n\nThis may not be the same as the purchase price, as the property may have been purchased at a discount, repairs or updated may have been made, the property has appreciated over time, etc.

The portion of the property\'s market value that you own. If using a loan, this depends on the balance of the loan. Equity will increase as the loan is paid down and the property\'s value appreciates.

Instead of deducting the cost of purchasing a property all in one year, many country\'s require that the cost of a rental property be taken over the property\'s useful lifespan.\n\nIn the US, the useful lifespan of a property is considered 27.5 years. If ot in the US, check the local tax laws on rental property depreciation rules.
The portion of the mortgage payment which is the interest portion of the loan.\n\nIn some countries one can deduct the mortgage interest from one\'s taxes. Check local tax laws for more information.
Add any purchase costs/closing costs, which may include appraisal, property inspection, pest inspection, and homeowners\â€™ insurance for the first year. Note: the names must be unique.
Add any repair costs, which may include paint, flooring, appliances, cleaning, and updates. Note: the names must be unique.
Add any expenses per month, which may include property tax, insurance, 3rd party warranties, and lawn maintenance. Note: the names must be unique.
